qas.question: What were the first 256 code points of Unicode made identical to?
Why were the first 256 code points made identical to ISO-8859-1?

answers.text: to make it trivial to convert existing western text

qas.question: What does the "fullwidth forms" section of code points encompass?

answers.text: a full Latin alphabet that is separate from the main Latin alphabet

qas.question: What are the CJK languages referenced?
Latin is what kind of language?
What are Latin characters called when they are half width?

plausible_answers.text: to preserve distinctions used by legacy encodings

qas.question: Why do coders avoid duplicate characters?
The 256 initial points make it difficult to translate what kind of text?

context: <b4_0>The first 256 code points<b4_0/> were made identical to the content of <a0_0>ISO-8859-1<a0_0/> so as <a1_0>to make it trivial to convert existing <b8_0>western<b8_0/> text<a1_0/>. Many essentially identical characters were encoded multiple times at different code points <b7_0>to preserve distinctions used by legacy encodings<b7_0/> and therefore, allow conversion from those encodings to Unicode (and back) without losing any information. For example, the "<b6_0>fullwidth forms<b6_0/>" section of code points encompasses <a2_0>a full Latin alphabet that is separate from the main Latin alphabet<a2_0/> section because in <a3_0>Chinese, Japanese, and Korean<a3_0/> (<b5_0>CJK<b5_0/>) fonts, these Latin characters are rendered at the same width as CJK ideographs, rather than at half the width. For other examples, see Duplicate characters in Unicode.
